questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the OPD for a routine follow-up appointment. Her temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 76/min and irregular. ECG shows atrial fibrillation with no ischemic changes. Anticoagulation therapy with warfarin is initiated for stroke prevention. Two days later, the patient is hospitalized with severe skin and subcutaneous fat necrosis. Drug effects on which of the following processes are most likely responsible for this patient's skin findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Protein C activity

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the OPD due to worsening shortness of breath for several months. The patient has no fever, weight loss, or cough.  Pulmonary examination demonstrates wheezing. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Total bilirubin: 1.3mg/dl

 

AST: 112 U/L

 

ALT: 124 U/L

 

A liver biopsy is subsequently performed and show below. Given these findings, which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's shortness of breath?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Interalveolar septal destruction

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department after experiencing sudden-onset headache with brief loss of consciousness while working in his yard. CT scan of the brain reveals blood in the basal cistern from a ruptured intracranial aneurysm. The patient is hospitalized, and endovascular coiling of the aneurysm is performed. Over the next several days, his symptoms gradually improve but the patient develops worsening hyponatremia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hyponatremia?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Increased antidiuretic hormone secretion)

questions.text: A physiological control system exhibits a gain of 0.6. If a change in the input stimulus leads to a corresponding 12% change in the controlled variable, what is the magnitude of the alteration in the input stimulus that would result in a 30% change in the controlled variable?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1.25 units

questions.text: A 19-year-old male severs an artery in a motorcycle accident. A bystander applies a tourniquet to stop the bleeding. When the paramedics arrived, the blood pressure of the injured man was only slightly hypotensive, and his pupils were reactive. The greatest percentage of the redistributed blood volume came from which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Venules and veins

questions.text: A 54-year-old previously healthy man comes to the OPD due to several weeks of leg swelling. He has had no fever, chest pain, or dyspnea. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. A mobile left flank mass can be palpated. There are several vertically oriented tortuous veins on the lower abdominal wall. Which of the following structures is most likely obstructed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior vena cava

 

  • The patient has leg swelling, a mobile left flank mass (likely a renal mass), and vertically oriented tortuous veins on the lower abdominal wall.
  • These superficial veins suggest collateral circulation due to obstruction of the inferior vena cava (IVC), which causes blood to be diverted through superficial abdominal veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral veins and Option B. Iliac veins: Obstruction of femoral or iliac veins would typically cause unilateral leg swelling without prominent abdominal wall veins.

 

Option D. Portal vein: Portal vein obstruction leads to portal hypertension and dilated veins around the umbilicus (caput medusae), which are radiating veins, not vertical.

questions.text:
Part 2 of 2

Further evaluation of the patient reveals microscopic hematuria. Laboratory results are as follows:

Leukocytes: 9,000/mm³

Hemoglobin: 19.2 g/dL

Platelets: 230,000/mm³

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hematologic findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Excess erythropoietin production

 

  • The patient has leg swelling, a left flank mass, microscopic hematuria, and a very high hemoglobin (19.2 g/dL).
  • These findings suggest a renal cell carcinoma (RCC), which often produces ectopic erythropoietin, leading to secondary polycythemia (elevated hemoglobin).
  • Microscopic hematuria and a palpable flank mass are classic signs of RCC.
  • The elevated hemoglobin is due to excess erythropoietin production by the tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arteriovenous malformation: May cause hematuria but not typically polycythemia.

 

Option C. Extramedullary hematopoiesis: Occurs in chronic marrow failure states, not typically with hematuria or flank masses.

 

Option D. Myeloproliferative disorder: Can cause polycythemia but does not explain the flank mass or hematuria.

choices.text: Incomplete closure of anterior abdominal wall

questions.text:
A 2-week-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents for evaluation of his umbilicus. The parents report that since the umbilical cord stump separated 2 days ago, there has been serous pale drainage from the umbilicus that increases when the patient cries. He is exclusively breastfed and continues to have normal wet diapers and stool output.

 

Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL

 

Platelets: 240,000/mm3

 

TLC: 11,000/mm3

 

Neutrophils: 60%

 

Lymphocytes: 32%

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's umbilical findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Persistence of allantois remnant

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the OPD due to increasing shortness of breath over the past 3 weeks. He has had a nonproductive cough for several months, which he attributes to allergies, but also notes a 9-kg unintentional weight loss over this time.  He has a 50-pack-year smoking history. Chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following would be the expected physical examination finding over the right lower chest?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Decreased tactile fremitus

choices.text: Decreased conversion of T4 to T3

questions.text: A 52-year-old, post-menopausal woman comes to the OPD for a follow-up appointment. Six months ago, the patient was evaluated for recurrent, brief episodes of excessive warmth and sweating, which were interfering with her usual activities. Thyroid hormone levels were normal, and the patient was subsequently diagnosed with menopausal hot flashes. Treatment with estrogen-containing hormone replacement therapy was begun with significant symptom improvement. Which of the following most likely occurred in this patient as a result of her medication use?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased total T4 level

 

Estrogen therapy increases thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG), leading to an increase in total T4 levels, while free T4 remains normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased conversion of T4 to T3: Estrogen does not significantly affect T4 to T3 conversion.

 

Option B. Decreased thyroid iodine uptake: Iodine uptake by the thyroid is unaffected.

 

Option C. Decreased TSH level: TSH levels remain largely unchanged if free T4 is normal.

questions.text: 54-year-old man comes to the physician due to blood in his urine and abdominal discomfort that occurred 2 days ago. He was moving potted plants around his porch when he started having pain in his abdomen. Afterward, he noticed blood in his urine but says it resolved the following day. He has a history of hypertension. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) ADPKD

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not require dose reduction in patients with renal failure?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Doxycycline

questions.text: An infant of 2 months had a serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. The mother might have taken which of the following drugs during the third trimester for this to occur?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Co-trimoxazole

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of confusion, fatigue, and abdominal pain. He has also experienced excessive thirst and polyuria during the last 3 weeks. Urine dipstick is positive for glucose and ketones. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the development of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Islet leukocytic infiltration

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to 4 weeks of worsening cough, shortness of breath, and low-grade fevers. She also has had an unintentional weight loss of 4.5 kg over the past 3 months. Pulse oximetry shows 86% on ambient air. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral crackles. There are no heart murmurs, and jugular venous pressure is normal. Chest x-ray reveals diffuse interstitial infiltrates. The patient undergoes bronchoscopy; bronchoalveolar lavage specimen is shown in the image.

 

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is hospitalized with fever and persistent sore throat. There are several bruises on his trunk, and blood is oozing from his intravenous catheter venipuncture sites. His blood fibrinogen level is 110 mg/dL (normal 150-400 mg/ dL). Bone marrow biopsy is shown below. Chromosomal analysis of these immature cells is most likely to show which of the following abnormalities?
questions.solution: Ans. D) t (15;17)

questions.text:
60-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to bilateral flank pain and hematuria. Medical history is significant for recurrent urinary tract infections and hypothyroidism. Blood pressure is 130/80 mm g and pulse is 80/min. CT scan of the abdomen is shown below:

 

 

Urinalysis for this patient would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) pH 8.0

 

  • Recurrent UTIs, especially with urease-producing bacteria (like Proteus mirabilis), can alkalinize urine, leading to pH ≥8.
  • Alkaline urine promotes struvite stone formation, which explains the flank pain and hematuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4+ protein: Seen in nephrotic syndrome, not typical for UTI or stones.

 

Option B. Eosinophils: Seen in allergic interstitial nephritis, not in UTIs or stones.

 

Option D. RBC casts: Suggest glomerular origin hematuria (glomerulonephritis), not UTI-related stones.

 

Key point: Recurrent UTIs → alkaline urine (pH 8) → struvite stones.

questions.text: A motorcyclist suffered a head injury 6 months back and presents with persistent memory deficits following injury. Choose the most appropriately matched option related to memory?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medial Temporal lobe - Declarative memory

 

  • The medial temporal lobe, including the hippocampus, is critical for the formation and consolidation of declarative memory (facts and events).
  • Hippocampus specifically supports declarative, not implicit memory (which is procedural and involves other brain regions like the striatum).
  • Neocortex is involved in higher-order processing and storage of semantic memory but not specifically associative learning per se.
  • Angular gyrus is involved in language and number processing but not procedural memory,

questions.text: A 45-year-old man reports coarsening of his facial features over several years. In addition, he reports low libido and decreased energy. Physical examination shows frontal bossing and enlarges hands. Which of the following screening tests should be ordered?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. IGF-1
 

Serum IGF-1 is the preferred screening test for acromegaly, reflecting chronic GH excess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24-Hour UFC: 24-hour UFC screens for Cushing’s syndrome.

 

Option B. S. ACTH: Serum ACTH measures adrenal function, not GH excess.

 

Option C. Fasting GH levels: Fasting GH levels fluctuate and are unreliable for screening.

questions.text: 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He is comatose and unable to provide any information. Multiple blunt injuries of the torso and abdomen are present. Review of the patient's medical record reveals a history of right upper lobe cavitary tuberculosis that was effectively treated several years ago. A representative slice of the chest CT, shown in the image below, redemonstrates his known right upper lobe cavity. Which of the following best describes this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic colonization

 

The presence of a pre-existing lung cavity from prior tuberculosis is a common site for chronic colonization by fungi such as Aspergillus, forming a fungus ball (aspergilloma) without tissue invasion.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Allergic inflammation: Refers to allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, which involves airway inflammation, not colonization of a cavity.

 

Option C. Invasive malignancy: Would show a mass with tissue invasion and destruction, not a noninvasive fungus ball.

 

Option D. Heterotopic calcification: Refers to abnormal calcification of soft tissues, unrelated to lung cavities.

choices.text: Binding of activated receptors to DNA to modify transcription

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the OPD for evaluation of short stature. Her parents have noticed that she bears little resemblance to her 2 older siblings. Other findings include low-set ears, a high arched palate, a webbed neck, and cubitus valgus. Chromosomal analysis reveals a 45, XO karyotype. The patient is started on a medication to improve growth and normalize her height. Which of the following intracellular pathways is stimulated by the medication used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) JAK-STAT pathway

 

The patient has Turner syndrome and is treated with growth hormone, which acts via the JAK-STAT pathway to stimulate IGF-1 production and promote growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Binding of activated receptors to DNA to modify transcription: DNA-binding receptors are typical of steroid hormones, not growth hormone.

 

Option B. Cyclic AMP-Protein kinase A pathway: cAMP-PKA pathway is used by hormones like ACTH or TSH.

 

Option C. Diacylglycerol-Protein kinase C pathway: DAG-PKC pathway is utilized by IP3/DAG signaling hormones.

choices.text: Hydrogen ion secretion from the collecting duct
Na/K/2Cl cotransport in the thick ascending limb
Hydrogen ion secretion from the DCT
Urea reasorption in the collecting duct

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the OPD for a follow-up appointment. He has a history of systolic heart failure, which has been managed with appropriate medical therapy. The patient experiences significant functional impairment at baseline and is able to walk only short distances. His most recent echocardiogram revealed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30% (normal ≥55%). The physician decides to add spironolactone to the treatment regimen. The addition of this medication is most likely to cause a decrease in which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Hydrogen ion secretion from the collecting duct

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the OPD due to 3 months of progressive fatigue and back pain. The back pain occurs mainly with movement or positional changes. Physical examination reveals midline tenderness over the middle and lower back. Laboratory evaluation shows a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL and serum calcium level of 12 mg/dL. A bone marrow aspirate is performed, and the histopathologic findings are shown below. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amyloidosis

 

  • The patient's symptoms (progressive fatigue, back pain with movement, midline spinal tenderness), laboratory findings (anemia, hypercalcemia), and the bone marrow aspirate (showing numerous plasma cells) are classic for multiple myeloma.
  • Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy that produces large amounts of abnormal immunoglobulin light chains.
  • These light chains can deposit in various tissues, leading to amyloidosis (specifically AL amyloidosis), causing organ dysfunction.
  • Amyloidosis is a well-known complication in patients with multiple myeloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cardiac tamponade and Option D. Hyperthyroidism: They are not directly related to multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. Hepatic failure: Hepatic failure can occur in advanced disease but is not a common or primary risk compared to amyloidosis.

questions.text: Several residents of a jail develop febrile illness within a short period of time. Symptoms include fever, nonproductive cough, myalgia, rigors, dyspnea, and diarrhea. Organisms found in induced sputum samples stain poorly with Gram stain but are visualized easily using silver stain. Urine testing for bacterial antigens is positive in most of the affected individuals. Which of the following is the most likely source of this outbreak?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Building water-distribution system

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with pseudohypoparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low PTH
 

Pseudohypoparathyroidism features resistance to PTH, so PTH levels are elevated, not low.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low calcium: Low calcium occurs due to end-organ resistance to PTH.

 

Option C. Short 4th and 5th metacarpals: Short 4th and 5th metacarpals are a classic finding (Albright hereditary osteodystrophy).

 

Option D. Short stature: Short stature is commonly seen in this condition.

questions.text: During starvation, a graph of three substances are plotted as below. The scale for A and B is on the left and the scale for C is on the right. Which of the substances are represented by the curve B?
questions.solution: Ans. C) T3

choices.text: Low serum triiodothyronine level

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to a 2-week history of neck pain. The patient had an upper respiratory infection a month ago that resolved spontaneously. The patient then felt well until 2 weeks ago, when she developed pain in the anterior neck associated with mild fever, palpitations, and excessive sweating. The thyroid gland is tender to palpation and diffusely enlarged. The Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 70 mm/hr. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient currently?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Low radioactive iodine uptake

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the hospital due to progressive fatigue and weakness. Medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and obesity. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Sodium: 138 mEq/L

 

Chloride: 110 mEq/L

 

Bicarbonate: 18 mEq/L

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Renal tubular acidosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of exertional dyspnea and dry cough for 8 months. Oxygen saturation on room air while lying down is 96% and drops to 88% after 6 minutes of walking. Examination shows fine crackles in both lower lungs. Chest x-ray reveals reticular densities in both lung fields. Lung biopsy shows an infiltration of inflammatory cells, predominantly lymphocytes, as well as poorly formed noncaseating granulomas and moderate alveolar septal fibrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

 

The presence of lymphocytic infiltration, noncaseating granulomas, and fibrosis with exertional desaturation suggests hypersensitivity pneumonitis due to repeated antigen exposure. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Characterized by reversible airway obstruction, not fibrosis or granulomas. 

 

Option B. Chronic bronchitis: A clinical diagnosis with mucus hypersecretion, not granulomatous inflammation. 

 

Option D. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Usually shows usual interstitial pneumonia pattern without granulomas.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 8 weeks gestation comes to the OPD due to pain and swelling of her left leg for the past day. The patient had a pulmonary embolism during her previous pregnancy, and prophylactic low-molecular-weight heparin therapy was initiated 6 days ago. She has no other medical conditions and takes prenatal vitamins. Venous duplex ultrasonography reveals acute left femoral vein thrombosis. Platelet count, which was normal prior to anticoagulant therapy initiation, is 84,000/mm3. Other blood cell counts, and renal and liver function studies are within normal limits. Which of the following most likely predisposed this patient to her current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Anti-platelet factor 4 antibodies

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to confusion, nausea, and decreased arousal. Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), pulse is 86/min, and respirations are 22/min. Arterial blood gas and serum chemistry results are as follows:

 

pH 7.25

 

PaO2: 96 mm Hg

 

PaCO2: 28 mm Hg

 

Sodium: 136 mEq/L

 

Potassium: 3.6 mEq/L

 

Chloride: 90 mEq/L

 

Bicarbonate: 12 mEq/L

 

Blood urea nitrogen: 30 mg/dL

 

Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL

 

Which of the following is the most likely primary acid-base disorder in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Anion gap metabolic acidosis

choices.text: Life expectancy will be shorter than average
Mean corpuscular volume will be decreased
She has relative protection from Plasmodium falciparum

questions.text:
A 2-week-old girl is brought to her primary care provider for a routine visit. Newborn screening results from hemoglobin electrophoresis are as follows:

 

Hemoglobin F: 70%

 

Hemoglobin A: 20%

 

Hemoglobin S: 10%

 

Examination shows a well-appearing infant with no pallor or splenomegaly. Which of the following is most likely true about this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) She has relative protection from Plasmodium falciparum

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with a head injury from a car accident was brought to the emergency department by ambulance. On exam, she had a respiratory rate of 8 breaths per minute, and a prolonged duration of inhalation was noted. Damage to which of the following groups of neurons in the brainstem is most likely responsible for this abnormal respiration?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumotaxic center 

 

The pneumotaxic center regulates the rate and pattern of breathing by limiting inspiration duration; damage leads to prolonged inhalation and decreased respiratory rate. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Dorsal respiratory group: Controls basic rhythm of inspiration but not inspiratory duration specifically. 

 

Option B. Nucleus tractus solitarius: Processes sensory information related to respiration but not direct control of breathing pattern. 

 

Option D. Vasomotor center: Regulates blood pressure and vascular tone, unrelated to respiration.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the OPD due to daytime sleepiness and lack of energy. The symptoms began 6 months ago and have progressively worsened so that he feels "completely drained" by the end of the day. The patient's wife mentions that he snores loudly. The patient does not use tobacco or alcohol, and he works in the warehouse of an agricultural supply company. BMI is 34 kg/m2. Physical examination shows a narrow oropharynx and a large neck circumference. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is hospitalized for acute chest pain and undergoes PCI. His serum creatinine is unchanged 3 days post-procedure, but from day 4 slowly rises to a peak of 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis demonstrates no proteinuria or red blood cells, and a few granular casts are present. Serum complement is low. Blood counts show eosinophilia.  Which one of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atheroembolic disease

 

Atheroembolic renal disease occurs after vascular procedures (like PCI), due to cholesterol crystal embolization. It presents with rising creatinine days after procedure, eosinophilia, low complement, and bland urine sediment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic interstitial nephritis: Typically shows fever, rash, eosinophiluria, and WBC casts, not low complement.

 

Option B. CIN: Contrast nephropathy occurs within 24–48 hours, not delayed rise after 3–5 days.

 

Option D. RPGN: Characterized by rapid renal failure, hematuria, RBC casts, not seen here.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is hospitalized after injuring her right hip when she slipped on ice while carrying groceries. X-ray reveals a right femoral neck fracture, and the patient undergoes total hip arthroplasty with no operative complications. Two weeks after surgery, the patient develops acute hemodynamic decompensation. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest is immediately obtained.  In-hospital administration of which of the following is most appropriate for reducing the risk of patients developing this complication?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Low-molecular-weight heparin

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of weakness, fatigue, and pallor. She denies heavy menses or melena. Physical examination is unremarkable except for conjunctival pallor. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Hemoglobin: 7.2 g/dL

 

Erythrocyte count: 1.8 million/uL

 

Mean corpuscular volume: 90 fL

 

Reticulocytes: 0.1%

 

Platelets: 280,000 /uL

 

Leukocyte count: 6,700 cells/mm3

 

Iron studies and serum B12 and folic acid levels are within normal limits. \ Further workup would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Thymic tumor

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is being evaluated for nontender cervical lymphadenopathy that he first noticed while shaving. A biopsy is performed and is shown below. Cytogenetic analysis would most likely demonstrate which of the following patterns?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BCL-2 overexpression

 

  • The clinical presentation of nontender cervical lymphadenopathy in a young adult and the biopsy (likely showing a follicular pattern) suggests follicular lymphoma.
  • Follicular lymphoma is characterized by the t(14;18) translocation, which leads to overexpression of the BCL-2 protein.
  • BCL-2 overexpression prevents apoptosis, allowing neoplastic follicular center cells to survive longer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BCR-ABL rearrangement (Philadelphia chromosome): Seen in chronic myeloid leukemia.

 

Option C. C-MYC overexpression: Seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

 

Option D. Constitutive tyrosine kinase activation: Typically associated with myeloproliferative disorders and CML.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is more common in patients with dcSSC than in lcSSc?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Pulmonary fibrosis.

choices.text: Dry cough and exertional dyspnea

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with non-Hodgkin lymphoma is undergoing systemic chemotherapy. Vincristine is a part of the regimen, and you suspect accidental overdose of that agent. Which of the following would you most expect in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Finger numbness and tingling

questions.text: 65-year-old man comes to the OPD with a 2-day history of skin rash and low-grade fever. The patient was recently diagnosed with acute gouty arthritis and has been taking indomethacin for the past 10 days. Examination shows a diffuse, maculopapular skin rash. Mucosal surfaces are moist without any lesions. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormities. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Serum creatinine is 2.3 mg/dL (baseline 1.1 mg/dL, 2 weeks ago). Urinalysis shows numerous white blood cells/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acute renal dysfunction?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Interstitial nephritis

questions.text: All the following conditions are manifestations of IgG4RD except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crescentic glomerulonephritis

 

IgG4-related disease (IgG4-RD) is a fibroinflammatory condition characterized by tumefactive lesions, dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates rich in IgG4-positive plasma cells, and storiform fibrosis. 

 

Common manifestations include:

 

  • Autoimmune pancreatitis – pancreatic enlargement with obstructive jaundice.
  • Lymphoplasmacytic aortitis – thickening of the aortic wall.
  • Orbital pseudotumor – swelling of orbital tissues causing proptosis or diplopia.

 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis is usually immune-complex mediated (e.g., anti-GBM disease, ANCA vasculitis) and is not associated with IgG4-RD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune pancreatitis: Classic organ involvement in IgG4-RD.

 

Option C. Lymphoplasmacytic aortitis: IgG4-related large vessel inflammation.

 

Option D. Orbital pseudotumor: Common manifestation, often with lacrimal gland involvement.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He is found to have a laceration of the spleen and is taken for emergent laparotomy. During surgery, the patient goes into cardiac arrest and dies, despite aggressive resuscitation efforts. Autopsy examination is performed and shows areas of thickening inside the chest wall as shown below. Lung examination shows fibrosis of the lower lobes. Pathologic examination of these fibrotic areas is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ferruginous bodies

 

The thickening of the chest wall and lower lobe pulmonary fibrosis in the autopsy suggests asbestosis. Ferruginous bodies, iron-coated asbestos fibers, are characteristic histologic findings in asbestosis.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Alveolar hyaline membranes: Found in diffuse alveolar damage/acute respiratory distress syndrome, not chronic fibrosis from asbestos.

 

Option B. Birefringent silicate particles: Seen in silicosis caused by inhalation of silica dust.

 

Option C. Carbon-laden macrophages: Found in coal workers’ pneumoconiosis or anthracosis, related to coal dust exposure.

questions.text: 35-year-old woman presents with fever and pain in knees and ankles. On exam, she has B/L parotid swelling, and she has lesion shown in the picture below. Laboratory studies are normal except for a slightly increased calcium level. What is the most appropriate Rx?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corticosteroids

 

The most appropriate treatment is corticosteroids.

 

  • The image shows erythema nodosum—tender red nodules, primarily on the shins.
  • The case features: fever, migratory polyarthritis, bilateral parotid swelling, and mild hypercalcemia.
  • This constellation suggests sarcoidosis (classic Lofgren’s syndrome: erythema nodosum, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, fever, and arthritis).
  • First-line therapy for symptomatic sarcoidosis (especially with significant organ involvement) is corticosteroids to suppress inflammation and granuloma formation.

questions.text: Researchers measure the serum insulin levels of healthy volunteers after equivalent loads of oral (dotted line) and intravenous glucose (solid line). The following curves are observed. Which of the following endogenous substances best explains the difference between the curves?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucagon-like peptide-1

 

The graph shows higher insulin secretion after oral glucose (dotted line) compared to intravenous glucose (solid line). This difference is explained by the incretin effect, primarily due to glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1), an endogenous hormone released from the intestine after oral glucose that stimulates insulin secretion.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Insulin-like growth factor-1: Not directly involved in acute insulin secretion after glucose intake.

 

Option C. Somatostatin: Inhibits insulin secretion, would not account for the increased oral response.

 

Option D. Secretin: Regulates pancreatic secretion but does not significantly affect insulin release in response to glucose.

questions.text: How much drug will be left after 6 hours if a patient is given a dose of 200 mg and 75 mg is excreted in 90 minutes. (Assume that the drug follows first-order kinetics)?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 30.5 mg

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the OPD due to exertional dyspnea and cough. His symptoms started 6 months ago and have progressively worsened. Other medical conditions include peptic ulcer disease, and rheumatoid arthritis. The patient had taken a medication for rheumatoid arthritis for many years but stopped a year ago, as the drug failed to improve his worsening hand arthritis. Chest x-ray is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's pulmonary symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulmonary fibrosis

 

The patient's gradual onset exertional dyspnea, dry cough, history of rheumatoid arthritis, and chest X-ray findings suggest pulmonary fibrosis, which is a common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis and can cause progressive restrictive lung disease.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Bilateral atelectasis: Would present acutely with volume loss and more focal x-ray changes, not progressive symptoms.

 

Option B. Left ventricular failure: Causes pulmonary edema with signs of cardiomegaly and vascular redistribution on X-ray.

 

Option C. Obstructive lung disease: Characterized by hyperinflation and airway obstruction, typically seen in COPD or asthma, not fibrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following opioids is an antagonist at ‘µ’ and a complete agonist at ‘k’ receptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pentazocine

 

  • Pentazocine → It is a mixed agonist–antagonist opioid.

    • Acts as an antagonist (or weak partial agonist) at µ receptors, hence less risk of respiratory depression and euphoria.
    • Acts as a complete agonist at κ receptors, producing analgesia, sedation, and dysphoria.
    • Clinically used for moderate pain but limited due to psychotomimetic effects (hallucinations, dysphoria).

     

Partial agonist: Buprenorphine

 

Mixed agonist/antagonist: Nalbuphine, Pentazocine, Butorphanol

choices.text: Acute hemorrhage in the pituitary gland
Dissection of the internal carotid artery
Ischemic necrosis of pituitary gland

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to a severe, sudden-onset headache that started an hour ago. The patient reports that he has had mild headaches and decreased libido over the past 3 months. Physical examination reveals bilateral deficits involving the temporal visual fields and impaired extraocular eye movements. Shortly after being admitted to the hospital, he becomes acutely hypotensive and loses consciousness. The patient dies despite aggressive resuscitation efforts. Which of the following is most likely to be found in an autopsy?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Acute hemorrhage in the pituitary gland

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD due to persistent back pain, constipation, and easy fatigability for the last several months. Blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg and pulse is 88/ min. The patient has dry mucous membranes. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Hemoglobin 8.6 g/dL

 

Mean corpuscular volume: 92 fL

 

Blood urea nitrogen: 68 mg/dL

 

Creatinine: 1.9mg/dl

 

Renal biopsy is performed, and light microscopy shows atrophic tubules, many of which contain large, obstructing, waxy casts that stain intensely with eosin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Multiple myeloma

questions.text: Which of the following drugs need labelling as “Dangerous to use except under medical supervision”?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schedule G drugs

 

Schedule G drugs  require a warning: Caution: It is dangerous to take this preparation except under medical supervision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schedule H drugs: Prescription drugs, no specific wording.

 

Option C. Schedule J drugs: Drugs exempted from patent or licensing rules.

 

Option D. Schedule X drugs: Narcotics/psychotropic requiring special prescription.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is evaluated for progressive shortness of breath and dry cough. There is no significant family history. On physical examination, the lungs are clear to auscultation. Chest imaging studies reveal pulmonary infiltrations and hilar adenopathy. The patient undergoes lung biopsy; the findings are shown below. Which of the following sets of immune cells and cytokines is most likely responsible for the development of this patient's pathologic findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Th1, IL-2, interferon-Gamma

questions.text: A 42-year-old previously healthy woman comes to the OPD due to fever and sore throat. She has no cough. Physical examination shows tonsillar exudate and a nontender cervical lymph node that measures 3.5 cm in diameter. Oral antibiotic therapy is started and, on a follow-up, visit a week later, the patient reports that her symptoms have resolved. The previously enlarged cervical lymph node has decreased slightly in size. On several follow- up visits over the following year, the patient remains asymptomatic, and the size of the lymph node fluctuates but does not disappear completely. Referral to a surgeon is made and excisional biopsy of the lymph node is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Follicular lymphoma

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Misbranded drug.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman is brought to the hospital due to 2 days of nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and headache. She was recently hospitalized due to a stroke, and the hospitalization was complicated by a urinary tract infection and delirium. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and her treatment regimen includes theophylline. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 22/min. On physical examination, the patient appears agitated and restless. There is a coarse tremor of the outstretched arms. Chest auscultation reveals mild expiratory wheezing. Serum theophylline levels are markedly elevated. Treatment with which of the following agents most likely precipitated this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Ciprofloxacin

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is hospitalized following a motor vehicle collision complicated by severe hemorrhage. Over the next 8 hours his urine output is markedly decreased. Laboratory results reveal elevated blood urea nitrogen. The patient is given aggressive intravenous fluid hydration. After 24 hours of therapy, urine output is increased and blood urea nitrogen declines toward normal. Which of the following additional laboratory abnormalities suggests that this patient's initial oliguria is a compensation for volume contraction?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Urine fractional excretion of sodium <1%

choices.text: Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis

questions.text: Identify the wrongly matched pair of antifungals with its mechanism of action?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother for a yearly physical examination. The patient feels well but is worried that she has not yet started puberty. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure is 152/91 mmHg, pulse is 75/min, and respirations are 18/ min. Physical examination is significant for a lack of secondary sexual characteristics; a blind vagina is noted on pelvic examination. Laboratory studies reveal hypokalemia and low testosterone and estradiol levels. Cytogenetic analysis shows a 46, XY karyotype. This patient most likely has deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 17 alpha-hydroxylase

choices.text: Natural Killer cell lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma
Acute myeloid leukemia with RUNX1 mutation

questions.text: All leukemias come under provisional entity in WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid tumours except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) B-lymphoblastic leukemia/ lymphoma with hypodiploidy

choices.text: Surface area to volume ratio

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the OPD for a follow-up appointment. She has a history of immune thrombocytopenia that failed to improve with glucocorticoid therapy. The patient underwent splenectomy 6 months ago, which resulted in improved platelet counts. A peripheral blood smear is shown below. An increase in which of the following features best explains the presence of these abnormal cells?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Surface area to volume ratio

choices.text: There is enzymatic digestion of cellular contents
It is associated with adjacent inflammation
Plasma membrane remains intact

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about apoptosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Plasma membrane remains intact

choices.text: Increased levels of insulin-like growth factor-1
Inhibition of osteoblast precursor cell replication and differentiation
Inhibition of receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa B

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to polymyalgia rheumatica. She was diagnosed a year ago and has required supraphysiologic doses of predisone to control her symptoms. She has adequate intake of calcium and vitamin D from her diet and supplements. Bone density measured by dual x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) reveals a significant decline when compared to her bone density measured at age 65. Which of the following is most likely contributing to this patient's bone loss?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Inhibition of osteoblast precursor cell replication and differentiation

choices.text: Alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen
Alpha 5 chain of type IV collagen

questions.text: 26-year-old previously healthy man comes to the OPD with a 3-week history of shortness of breath, cough, and hemoptysis preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection. His blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg and pulse is 86/min and regular. Physical examination reveals bilateral inspiratory crackles and lower extremity edema. His creatinine is 4.1 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria with dysmorphic red blood cells. Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates are seen on chest x-ray. He is also found to have an increased carbon monoxide diffusing capacity (DLCO) on pulmonary function testing. Antibodies directed against which of the following is most likely to be associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen

 

This is Goodpasture syndrome, presenting with pulmonary hemorrhage + rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Caused by autoantibodies against the α3 chain of type IV collagen in basement membranes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Beta-hemolytic streptococci: Cause post-streptococcal GN, not associated with lung hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Alpha 5 chain of type IV collagen: Mutation causes Alport syndrome, not autoimmune GN.

 

Option D. Double-stranded DNA: Antibodies are seen in lupus nephritis, not with pulmonary hemorrhage.

choices.text: Platelets is stored between 20°c to 24°C with a shelf life of 5 days
Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°C with a shelf life of 6 months
Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol and saline is stored between -5°C to -15 °C with a shelf life of 5 weeks
Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15° C with a shelf life of 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about blood products?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Platelets is stored between 20°c to 24°C with a shelf life of 5 days

questions.text: A 1-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department with poor feeding, lethargy, and unusual "muscle movements" involving the left thumb and hand over the last 2 days. The infant's vital signs are normal, but unusual flexion of the left wrist and thumb and extension of the fingers are observed with cuff blood pressure measurement. Physical examination reveals a hypoplastic mandible, low-set ears, bifid uvula, and cleft palate. A chest x-ray is shown below.These findings most likely suggest impaired development of which of the following embryonic structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Third pharyngeal pouch

 

This case describes a neonate with congenital anomalies (facial dysmorphisms, cleft palate), carpopedal spasm with BP cuff inflation (Trousseau sign—indicative of hypocalcemia), and a chest X-ray showing absent thymic shadow. These findings are characteristic of DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome), involving defective development of the third (and fourth) pharyngeal pouch.

 

  • The third pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the inferior parathyroids and thymus. Failure of this pouch leads to hypocalcemia (hypoparathyroidism) and immunodeficiency (thymic aplasia, absent thymic shadow).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foramen cecum: Located at the junction of the tongue and oral cavity; it marks the origin of the thyroid diverticulum. Has no role in thymus or parathyroid gland development. Defects cause thyroid abnormalities (e.g., ectopic thyroid).

 

Option C. Rathke pouch: An ectodermal outpouching from the roof of the oral cavity; gives rise to the anterior pituitary (adenohypophysis). Defects affect pituitary hormone production.

 

Option D. Second pharyngeal cleft: Usually obliterated during development; persists as branchial cyst if not. Defects result in lateral neck cysts, not immunodeficiency or hypocalcemia.

questions.text: 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to several days of worsening exertional dyspnea and lethargy. The patient has a history of sickle cell disease and takes hydroxyurea. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and a systolic ejection murmur. Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin level of 5.6 g/dL. Bone marrow biopsy is performed and demonstrates decreased erythroid precursors and giant pronormoblasts containing inclusions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Acute viral infection

questions.text: The phlebotomist needs to collect samples from a patient for various tests. Among the options provided, which sequence of blood collection for testing ensures that the sample remains uncontaminated, considering the additives present in the collection tubes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

 

  • Light blue (Citrate tube): Collected first to avoid contamination with clot activators or EDTA that can affect coagulation studies.
  • Red (Plain tube, no anticoagulant): Collected next for serology/chemistry, avoids interference from EDTA or fluoride.
  • Lavender (EDTA tube): Collected later for hematology; prevents EDTA carryover from affecting earlier tests.
  • Grey (Fluoride oxalate tube): Collected last for glucose/lactate estimation, since fluoride inhibits glycolysis and would interfere with other tests if drawn earlier.

choices.text: A bolus injection of insulin

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer. Following, surgery the patient develops perioral numbness and spasm of the muscles of her hand. The latter change is due to a change in the resting membrane potential of cells. Which of the below mentioned conditions will have a similar effect on the RMP of a cell?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Conn’s syndrome

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is non-essential in the evaluation of mosaic Turner syndrome?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Anti-nuclear antibodies

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to worsening leg swelling for the past 2 months. She has also felt excessively tired and has had achy pain in her hands. Serum creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL. Urinalysis is positive for proteinuria and hematuria. Light microscopy of samples from a kidney biopsy shows diffuse, global endocapillary hypercellularity. Direct immunofluorescence demonstrates staining with diffuse, global, granular staining of glomerular capillary walls by IgG, IgM, IgA, C1q, and C3. Electron microscopy will demonstrate which of the following changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subendothelial deposits

 

  • This is diffuse proliferative GN (often lupus nephritis), classically with subendothelial deposits.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Mesangial deposits: IgA nephropathy.

 

Option C. Subepithelial deposits: Membranous nephropathy.

 

Option D. Intra-membranous: Dense deposit disease.

questions.text: 60-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to difficulty climbing stairs and dyspnea on exertion over the last 6 weeks. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min. Skin examination shows scattered ecchymoses. Laboratory results show mild hyperglycemia and elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol. Serum cortisol level is at the upper limit of normal and is not suppressed following administration of low-dose dexamethasone. Serum ACTH level is elevated. Chest x-ray reveals a right lower lobe lung mass. Which of the following changes in ACTH and cortisol are most likely to occur after administration of high-dose dexamethasone in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Both unchanged

questions.text: 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics following a motor vehicle accident. He was an unrestrained passenger in the front seat. Several days after hospitalization, his fluid volume and plasma osmolarity are measured and illustrated in the image below (solid line, normal; dotted line, patient). Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause the findings shown in the image?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Diabetes insipidus

choices.text: Loss of glomerular basement membrane anions
Thinning of the glomerular basement membrane

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with generalized edema that developed following a mild upper respiratory infection. Blood pressure and heart rate are normal. Serum creatinine levels are normal. Urinalysis shows massive proteinuria with no hematuria. Further analysis reveals that urine protein consists principally of albumin with only trace amounts of IgG and alpha-2-macroglobulin. Which of the following pathologic changes is the most likely cause of this patient's urinary protein loss?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Loss of glomerular basement membrane anions

questions.text: A 24-year-old man met with an RTA and was brought to the casualty after 6 hours. His B.P. was 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate was 110/min, and Sp02 was 92%. A blood transfusion was done. After a few hours, the patient is febrile, tachypneic, and starts bleeding from the IV and NG tube sites. His SpO2 levels started falling. What could be the cause?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Acute hemolytic Transfusion reaction

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Papanicolaou stain?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Eosin B

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely mediator responsible for the effects of glucagon?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Protein kinase A

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is diagnosed with breast cancer. Her tumor is found to be HER2-positive but estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) negative. The tumor was resistant to trastuzumab. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be effective in the treatment of this patient's breast cancer?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Lapatinib

questions.text: Which of the following cells secrete a substance that controls iron storage and release by other cells involved in iron homeostasis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Hepatic parenchymal cells

questions.text: All of following drugs promotes bone formation except?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Bisphosphonates

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the office due to paroxysmal episodes of breathlessness and wheezing for the past 6 months. He had eczema as a child. The patient has no other medical conditions and takes no medications. Lung examination shows good air movement and no wheezing. Sputum microscopy reveals many granule-containing cells and crystalloid masses. The sputum findings in this patient are a direct result of which of the following cytokines?
questions.solution: Ans. B) IL-5

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to prolonged epistaxis. The girl says that she picked her nose immediately before the bleeding started. Her parents decided to take her to the emergency department after the epistaxis persisted for 20 minutes despite constant compression.  The patient has had frequent nosebleeds that often last >10 minutes. Laboratory tests are ordered, and results are as follows:

 

Hematocrit: 43%

 

Bleeding time: prolonged

 

Partial thromboplastin time (PTT): prolonged

 

Prothrombin time (PT): normal

 

Thrombin time (TT): normal

 

D-dimer: normal

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) von Willebrand disease 

 

  • The patient presents with prolonged bleeding time and prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT), but with normal prothrombin time (PT) and normal thrombin time (TT), consistent with a defect in the intrinsic pathway.
  • von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder and causes defective platelet adhesion, leading to prolonged bleeding time.
  • vWD also causes prolonged PTT because von Willebrand factor stabilizes factor VIII; its deficiency decreases factor VIII levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XIll deficiency: Factor XIII deficiency causes normal coagulation tests but abnormal wound healing and bleeding.

 

Option B. Hemophilia A: Hemophilia A causes prolonged PTT but normal bleeding time.

 

Option C. Vitamin K deficiency: The normal PT differentiates it from vitamin K deficiency, which prolongs both PT and PTT.

choices.text: Compliance low, FRC high, Airway resistance high
Compliance low, FRC low, Airway resistance high
Compliance high, FRC high, Airway resistance high
Compliance high, FRC high, Airway resistance low

questions.text: A 1-hour-old boy born at 29 weeks gestation via cesarean delivery due to maternal preeclampsia with severe features, is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for respiratory failure. Which of the following best describes the condition of this patient's lungs compared to a normal neonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Compliance low, FRC low, Airway resistance high 

 

Premature neonates typically have decreased lung compliance and lower functional residual capacity (FRC) due to immature surfactant production. Airway resistance is increased due to smaller airway caliber and immature lung structure. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Compliance low, FRC high, Airway resistance high: FRC is usually low, not high, in preterm infants. 

 

Option C. Compliance high, FRC high, Airway resistance high: Compliance is typically low in premature lungs. 

 

Option D. Compliance high, FRC high, Airway resistance low: Both compliance and FRC are decreased in premature infants with respiratory failure.

questions.text: Cancer cells from a 23-year-old male with testicular cancer demonstrate high sensitivity to etoposide. The etoposide-killed cancer cells show a high number of double-stranded DNA fractures. These fractures are due to dysfunction of which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Topoisomerase Il

choices.text: B, C and D

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true?

 

  1. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary oedema
  2. Pethidine is used for treatment of pain due to biliary colic
  3. Indomethacin can cause headache
  4. Aspirin is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease
questions.solution: Ans. B) A, B and C

choices.text: Autoantibodies to host cell basement membranes
Immune complex deposition in glomerular mesangium
Thrombosis of glomerular capillaries

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for arthralgias. He had a cough and runny nose last week but otherwise has been in good health. Physical examination shows raised, red-purple papules, some of which have coalesced, over the patient's buttocks and thighs. The abdomen is soft with normal bowel sounds. Urinalysis results are as follows:

 

Protein 2+

 

Blood moderate

 

Leukocyte esterase: trace

 

Nitrites: negative

 

White blood cells: 1-2/hpf

 

Red blood cells (RBCs): many/hpf

 

Casts: RBC casts

 

Which of the following mechanisms is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's renal findings?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Immune complex deposition in glomerular mesangium

questions.text: A male patient with a psychotic disorder is receiving antipsychotic, antidepressant, and antihypertensive medication. He developed tachycardia and chest tightness all of a sudden. He was diagnosed with metabolic acidosis. The ECG revealed a widened QRS complex and a prolonged QT interval. Which of the following drugs is the cause of this?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Amitriptyline

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a prolonged history of systemic lupus erythematosus, treated with multiple medications is being evaluated on autopsy. Records from the patient's most recent office visit show an elevated blood pressure and examination findings of facial plethora, truncal obesity, and skin ecchymoses. The patient's adrenal glands is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Bilateral cortical atrophy

questions.text: An experiment is being conducted on dog blood pressure to study the effect of acetylcholine. The blood pressure is recorded at each intervention and is shown below. What does phase 4 in the graph indicate?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Nicotinic action of acetylcholine

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman with borderline personality disorder is brought to the emergency department after taking an undetermined number of pills. She is lethargic but arousable. She refuses to answer questions. Blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg and heart rate is 120/min and regular. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Sodium: 139 mEg/L

 

Potassium: 3.3 mEq/L

 

Chloride : 98 mEq/L

 

Bicarbonate: 13 mEq/L

 

Arterial blood gases on room air

 

pH: 7.46

 

PaCO2: 19 mmHg

 

PaO2: 96 mmHg

 

Oxygen saturation: 99%

 

Which of the following best describes this patient's acid-base disturbance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis

 

  • Low bicarb = metabolic acidosis, low CO2 = concurrent respiratory alkalosis → mixed disorder.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Acidosis + alkalosis (metabolic both) → Not fitting.

 

Option B. Respiratory acidosis → PaCO2 is low, so incorrect.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis → Not consistent with HCO3 13.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is evaluated due to persistent fever, fatigue, and sore throat. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly and symmetric posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Peripheral blood smear results are shown in the image below The atypical cells seen here are most likely an activated form of which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. B) CD8 lymphocytes

questions.text: Indications of chest drain in a parapneumonic effusion are all except:
questions.solution: Ans. D. Pleural fluid LDH > 1000

choices.text: FEV1 low, TLC low, DLCO low
FEV1 low, TLC high DLCO normal
FEV1 high, TLC high, DLCO normal
FEV1 low, TLC high, DLCO low

questions.text: Identify the PFT findings in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:
questions.solution: Ans. D) FEV1 low, TLC high, DLCO low

choices.text: Weight gain and edema

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse drug effect of pioglitazone?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Weight gain and edema

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator) allows thymic medullary epithelial cells to express peripheral tissue antigens, enabling negative selection of self-reactive T-cells and preventing autoimmunity.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: Involved in T-cell lineage commitment, not self-tolerance.

 

Option B. E2A: Transcription factor required for B-cell development.

 

Option C. Rag ½: Required for V(D)J recombination in T- and B-cell receptor formation.

questions.text:
Organize the given steps of Karyotyping into the accurate sequence.

 

  1. Collect cells by peripheral vein using a heparin syringe
  2. Culture in phytohaemoagglutinin
  3. Incubation at 37 degrees C for 3 days
  4. Harvest with colchicine
  5. Routine staining with Giemsa
questions.solution: Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

choices.text: Increasing cyclic AMP-mediated smooth muscle relaxation

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is evaluated due to frequent episodes of shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough. The patient has been hospitalized on several occasions because of these symptoms and recently required mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure.  The treatment regimen Is expanded to include a monoclonal antibody that binds circulating lgE, with the resulting complexes being subsequently cleared by reticuloendothelial cells. This medication is most likely to help this patient through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Decreasing airway inflammation.

choices.text: Autoimmune-induced loss of self-renewing hematopoietic stem cells
Bone marrow replacement by constitutively active tyrosine kinase-stimulated cells
Splenic hyperactivity with cell trapping by the reticuloendothelial system
Increased destruction of cells opsonized by glycoprotein Ilb/Illa-targeted autoantibodies

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to bloody stools. The abdomen is soft without organomegaly. Skin examination shows pallor and scattered bruises in various stages of healing throughout the trunk. Complete blood count results are as follows:

 

Hemoglobin: 7.2 g/dL

 

Mean corpuscular volume: 90 um³

 

Platelets: 10,000/mm³

 

Leukocytes: 1,050/mm³

 

Neutrophils: 5%

 

Lymphocytes: 95%

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Autoimmune-induced loss of self-renewing hematopoietic stem cells

choices.text: Plasma volume increase, Pulmonary arterial resistance increase, Cardiac output decrease
Plasma volume decrease, Pulmonary arterial resistance decrease, Cardiac output decrease
Plasma volume decrease, Pulmonary arterial resistance increase, Cardiac output increase
Plasma volume increase, Pulmonary arterial resistance decrease, Cardiac output decrease

questions.text: Which of the following changes will happen at high altitude?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Plasma volume decrease, Pulmonary arterial resistance increase, Cardiac output increase

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD with fatigue. He has hypertension and poorly controlled diabetes complicated by nephropathy and peripheral neuropathy. His renal function has declined steadily over the last few years.  On the graph below, area "C" shows the normal relationship between serum concentrations of free calcium and parathyroid hormone. Which of the following areas most likely represents this patient's current metabolic state?
questions.solution: Ans. A) A

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below:
questions.solution: Ans. D) XLD
